title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Without showing that I was anything but satisfied with theinformation I had received, I took leave of the pair, and wentdown to Arthur Street, and found out the house in which theyhad formerly lived with the bookfolder as a lodger. Myobject was to find out if any of the neighbours had noticedthe bookfolder leaving, or had heard her speak of her intendeddestination.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: " Turn up your books, and see if the June entries includethe death of one Agnes Hunter, Arthur Street," was mymagnificent command ; Mr Cowan obeyed, with a quiet grin,and soon stopped, '.vith the exclamation—"All right: here it is—'Agnes Hunter, aged thirty-one. Present—Thomas Hun'er.

title: Cleg Kelly, Arab of the City
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: in a race. And many had been the Arthur Streeturchins who had suffered a sore skin and a night inthe cells after being taken in dire offence. So ' theWarrior ' they called him, for an all-sufficient name.

title: Fishers of men,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: And as Mad Mag was well-looking in a bold, gusty way, though burnt so brown that her china-blue eyes made holes in her face, Knifer Jackson rather liked to be seen out of doors with his wife on Sunday afternoons. They went down the length of the pleasance, disappeared into a close, came out among the respectable houses in Arthur Street, and so down hill into the Queen's Park. There, as was customary, they went arm in arm.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: All this I could believe, even if I had only Holman'scase to judge by. He ascended a common stair in Arthur Street with a letterenclosed in a blue envelope in his hand. He ought to havegone to the top, but he did not.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: His name's Hunter, and he lives in the Potterrow. He wasin Arthur Street when my sister lodged wi' him, and I wadlike to ken what he flittit for if it wasna to escape justice? "

title: Cleg Kelly, arab of the city,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: For the ranger of that particular part of the hill was an old soldier of great size and surprising swiftness in a race. And many had been the Arthur Street urchins who had suffered a sore skin and a night in the cells after being  taken in dire offence. So " the Warrior " they called him, for an all-sufficient name.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: " Oh, here it is—Mrs Hunter, Arthur Street," he said, reading from the book. " Heart disease—two hours illness."

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: So far asI could see, nothing was to be gained and much was to beexpended by putting the bookfolder out of the way. After leaving Arthur Street, and while still studying thesepoints, it struck me as quite an easy matter to test the truth ofthe statements made by those neighbours without going nearthe cobbler at all, who, I felt assured, would have lied througha brick wall. The office of the registrar was not far off, andthither I turned with quickened interest.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Yet even at this,the last moment, it seemed as if he were only to accomplishthe task with a fight. As he passed along Richmond Street,he got a quick glimpse of the man whose watch he had stolen !A glimpse—nothing more ; for he was through the close towardsArthur Street like the wind. Down—down ! The stair atlast! Up he fnounted, found the door, rang the bell, and theletter was delivered ! But now he felt at what a cost the wholehad been accomplished.

title: Cleg Kelly, Arab of the City.
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: For the ranger of that particular part of the hill wasan old soldier of great size and surprising swiftness in arace. And many had been the Arthur Street urchins whohad suffered a sore skin and a night in the cells after being taken in dire offence. So " the Warrior " they calledhim, for an all-sufficient name.

title: Cleg Kelly, arab of the city,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: The Drabble was found trying to steal collars off a clothes-line at the back of Arthur Street. Cleg Kelly had no objections to this feat.
